text:
He got up with an effort. His head throbbed. 

“Going to sleep again?” Nastasya cried. “Are you ill?” 

He didn’t answer. 

“Do you want some tea?” 

“Afterwards,” he murmured, closing his eyes. 

Nastasya frowned and left. 

At two o’clock, she returned with soup. He lay still, the tea untouched. 

“Why are you lying like a log?” she shouted, disgusted. 

He sat up, silent, staring at the floor. 

“Are you ill or not?” 

“Afterwards,” he replied weakly. “You can go.” 

She lingered, pitying him, then stepped out. 

He gazed at the tea and soup. Slowly, he reached for the bread. 

He ate mechanically, three or four spoonfuls. His head ached less.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov struggles with illness and apathy while being cared for by Nastasya, who is concerned about his well-being.
